greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of ways to write 2*n as p + 2^k + 3^m with p prime and 2^k + 3^m a product of at most two distinct primes, where k and m are nonnegative integers.
comment: The even number 58958 cannot be written as p + 2^k + 3^m with p and 2^k + 3^m both prime.
Clearly, a(n) <= A303702(n). We note that a(n) > 0 for all n = 2..5*10^8.
See also A304034 for a related conjecture.
reference: J. R. Chen, On the representation of a larger even integer as the sum of a prime and the product of at most two primes, Sci. Sinica 16(1973), 157-176.
link: Zhi-Wei Sun, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Zhi-Wei Sun, Mixed sums of primes and other terms, in: Additive Number Theory (edited by D. Chudnovsky and G. Chudnovsky), pp. 341-353, Springer, New York, 2010.

Zhi-Wei Sun, Conjectures on representations involving primes, in: M. Nathanson (ed.), Combinatorial and Additive Number Theory II, Springer Proc. in Math. & Stat., Vol. 220, Springer, Cham, 2017, pp. 279-310. (See also arXiv:1211.1588 [math.NT], 2012-2017.)
results.author: _Zhi-Wei Sun_, May 04 2018
